I am sure there are more than just a few of us who have had plenty of
probl=
ems trying to get NEAT compiled and running. So posting something
that is w=
ell-tested would be really helpful. 
I could help you testing (or implement=
ing if greatly needed) using both
c++ and c#.

set it up and have it posted on Sourceforge by the end

onal standards by the time I release it. But at

ble names tXXX1 and crap3  anymore by then ;)

et some feedback from people and help

n't know of any now. I am sure once

> > Pl=
ease, by all means. A Sourceforge project is a great idea. It would
> be

> nice to see a general purpose cross-platform C++ implementation in a

centralized public location like Sourceforge. I haven't worked with

kland's code for the very reason that it was encumbered with all

t

shanemcdonaldryan@ wrote:
> > >
> > >   Hi,
> > >
> > > I am in the midst o=
f building a times series predicting framework
> > > based on Matt Buckland=
's windows c++ code.
> > >
> > > I've removed the visualization aspects.
> =
> >
> > > Made it compile under windows and Linux (the same code runs 250%
=
> > > faster under Linux BTW).
> > >
> > > Made a generalized framework for=
 loading time series patterns from a
> file.
> > >
> > > It is quite rough =
and undocumented but it allows you to simply edit
> a
> > > parameter file =
and present patterns to do time-series prediction
> using
> > > NEAT. I thi=
nk it is also quite fast and I have some plans that I
> will
> > > elucidat=
e on in my next message that could significantly speed it
> up.
> > >
> > >=
 I've also built a little tool to run the saved result network and
> > > ge=
nerate a CSV file. So you can load the times series as a graph in
> > > exc=
el and visualize the results of your networks prediction compared
> > > to =
the original time series.
> > >
> > > It has plenty of work that needs done=
 on it. But I figured I might
> > > create a Sourceforge page and post it i=
f anyone is interested?
> > >
> > > Thanks,
> > >
> > > Shane
